choices.text: 50 mg
30.5 mg
12.5 mg

questions.text: How much drug will be left after 6 hours if a patient is given a dose of 200 mg and 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes. (Assume that the drug follows first-order kinetics)?  (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 30.5 mg

 

This question can be solved by two methods.

 

Method 1: Using the fraction method

In 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time.

75 mg is excreted in 90 mins.

Therefore 75/200 = 3/8th of the drug is eliminated in 90 minutes.

Thus after 90 minutes, 1-3/8 = 5/8th portion of the drug is left behind.

6 hours = 4 * 90 minutes.

Or, in 6 hrs = (5/8) * (5/8) *(5/8)*(5/8)* 200 mg will be left behind

= 30.518 mg will be left behind.

 

Method 2: Using the formula

First we need to determine the elimination rate constant (k) and the half-life (t1/2) of the drug.

We know that 75 mg of the drug is excreted in 90 minutes (1.5 hours). This means that the amount remaining after 1.5 hours is 200 mg - 75 mg = 125 mg.

First, we can use the formula for first-order kinetics to find k:

k = {log (C0/Ct)} / t​

Where:

  • C0 ​is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • Ct ​is the concentration after time t (125 mg)
  • t is the time in hours (1.5 hours)

k = {log⁡ (200/125)} / 1.5

k={log⁡(1.6)} / 1.5

k ≈ 0.470/1.5

k ≈ 0.313 hr−1

Next, we find the half-life using the relationship between k and t1/2:

t1/2 = 0.693 /k

t1/2 ​= 0.693​/0.313

t1/2 = 2.21 hours

Now, we need to determine the amount of drug left after 6 hours. We use the first-order kinetics formula:

Ct = C0 × e−kt

Where:

  • C0 is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • k is the elimination rate constant (0.313 hr^-1)
  • t is the time (6 hours)

Ct = 200 × e−0.313×6

Ct = 200 × e−1.878

Ct = 200 × 0.153

Ct ≈ 30.5 mg

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous discharge. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What will be the management for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous discharge, and a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. These clinical features are suggestive of advanced cervical cancer. The involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the cervix to the surrounding tissues but not to the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina, which classifies it as Stage 2B cervical cancer. The standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer is chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy. This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of the treatment, reduce tumor size, and prevent further spread of the cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It may be used in conjunction with radiation, but not as a sole therapy in this stage.

 

Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy, is typically used for early-stage cervical cancer or in combination with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced stages. However, it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for Stage 2B.

 

Option D. Surgery: Surgery is generally not recommended for Stage 2B cervical cancer due to the extent of the disease spread to the parametrium. The preferred approach is chemoradiation to address both local and regional disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 2B cervical cancer, characterized by lateral parametrium involvement, is best managed with chemoradiation.

 

Staging of CA Cervix

 

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Chemoradiation can be offered at all stages

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Treatment of femoral shaft fractures can be operative or non-operative.
  • Operative fixation with intramedullary nailing is the gold standard treatment.
  • Other operative techniques include plate osteosynthesis and external fixation.
  • Closed treatment with traction, splinting, and casting may be temporary treatment.

 

Intramedullary Nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing (IMN) is the gold standard of treatment for femoral shaft fractures.
  • Early treatment in a stable patient within 24-48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection, and mortality.
  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • The insertion site of an IMN is outside the zone of injury, preserving the surrounding blood flow and retain the hematoma that contains beneficial bone growth factors.
  • It provides a strong and stable internal fixation that allows for early mobilization and weight-bearing, which is crucial for promoting healing and preventing complications.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure compared to other options like plate fixation, resulting in less tissue disruption and blood loss.
  • It helps in a faster recovery time and a quicker return to daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip Spica: This is a cast that extends from the waist to the toes and is not typically used for femoral shaft fractures due to the limited mobility it allows.

 

Option B. Above Knee Slab: An above-knee slab is a temporary cast that can be used for pain management and swelling reduction but doesn't provide enough stability for healing a fractured femoral shaft.

 

Option C. Above Knee Cast: Similar to an above-knee slab, a cast offers limited stability and wouldn't be suitable for the long-term treatment of this fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

choices.text: Naive B cells
Germinal center B cells

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and night sweats over the past three months. He has noticed painless swelling in his neck and armpits. Physical examination reveals generalized lymphadenopathy and mild splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis with a predominance of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. Peripheral blood smear reveals the presence of smudge cells, and flow cytometry shows cells expressing CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23, and negative for CD10. A lymph node biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Based on the immunophenotype and clinical features, from which cell type does CLL/SLL originate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Naive B cells

 

 

Explanation:

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL) originates from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells. These cells have not yet undergone somatic hypermutation or class-switch recombination typical of germinal center B cells. CLL/SLL is characterized by the accumulation of these small, mature B lymphocytes in the blood, bone marrow, and lymphoid tissues. Flow cytometry typically shows a characteristic immunophenotype, including the expression of CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23, and lack of CD10, aligning with the cell of origin being naive or post-germinal center B cells.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Germinal center B cells
Germinal center B cells give rise to other types of lymphomas, such as follicular lymphoma, but are not the origin of CLL/SLL. Germinal center cells typically undergo somatic hypermutation, which is not a feature of CLL/SLL cells.

 

Option C. Plasma cells
Plasma cells are differentiated B cells responsible for antibody production and are not involved in the pathogenesis of CLL/SLL. Plasma cell dyscrasias, such as multiple myeloma, originate from plasma cells, distinct from CLL/SLL.

 

Option D. T cells
T cells are involved in the pathogenesis of T-cell lymphomas and are unrelated to CLL/SLL. CLL/SLL specifically involves B lymphocytes, not T lymphocytes.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL) originates from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, characterized by a distinct immunophenotype including CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Recognizing the cellular origin is essential for understanding the disease’s pathology and guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.text: Absolute refractory period is due to? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels. During this period, a second action potential cannot be elicited, even with a strong stimulus. A new action potential cannot occur in an excitable fiber as long as the membrane is still depolarized from the preceding action potential. This is because shortly after the action potential is initiated, the sodium channels become inactivated, and no amount of excitatory signal applied to these channels at this point will open the inactivation gates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Opening of calcium channels: Incorrect. The opening of calcium channels is not related to the absolute refractory period.

 

Option B. Closure of potassium channels: Incorrect. The closure of potassium channels does not define the absolute refractory period.

 

Option C. Closure of active gates of sodium channel: Incorrect. The closure of active gates does not account for the absolute refractory period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels, preventing the initiation of a new action potential during this period.

questions.text:
What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Wide local excision
  2. Axillary node dissection
  3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery
  4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Wide local excision:

 

  • This involves the removal of the breast tumor and a margin of surrounding normal tissue. The goal is to ensure that no cancer cells remain at the site, while preserving as much of the breast's appearance and function as possible.

 

2. Axillary node dissection:

 

  • This procedure involves removing lymph nodes from the axilla to check for the spread of cancer. If the sentinel lymph node biopsy (a procedure to remove the first node(s) that breast cancer is likely to spread) shows cancer, more extensive lymph node surgery might be done.

 

3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery:

 

  • A frozen section involves rapidly freezing a tissue sample from the patient during surgery. A pathologist then examines the tissue under a microscope. This procedure allows for an immediate diagnosis, which can guide surgical decisions during the procedure, such as whether wider excision is needed if margins are not clear.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional:

 

  • This statement is incorrect in the context of Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS). Post-operative radiotherapy is essential after BCS to reduce the risk of local recurrence of the tumor in the preserved breast tissue. It is not optional; rather, it's a standard part of the treatment plan in most cases.

 

Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:

 

a. Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor

 

b. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative)

 

c. Post-operative radiotherapy – given in all cases of BCT

 

d. If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

choices.text: Unfractionated Heparin
Low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Low molecular weight heparin

 

LMWH is the anticoagulant of choice for the treatment of Cancer associated thromboembolism. It has a long half-life, higher bioavailability and does not require anticoagulant monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unfractionated Heparin: While effective, it requires continuous intravenous infusion and frequent monitoring of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), making it less convenient for long-term management.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin requires regular monitoring of the international normalized ratio (INR) to maintain therapeutic levels, which can be challenging in cancer patients due to potential drug interactions and varying dietary intake.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. Although effective, it is not the first choice for cancer-associated thromboembolism due to limited evidence compared to LMWH and potential for drug interactions and gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for managing cancer-associated thromboembolism due to its long half-life, higher bioavailability, and the convenience of not requiring routine anticoagulant monitoring.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and was brought to emergency with stable vitals. Which wound is not expected:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chop wound

 

In the context of a road traffic accident, different types of wounds can be expected depending on the nature of the injury.

 

Chop Wound typically caused by a heavy, sharp tool like an axe or a machete. These are not typically seen in road traffic accidents unless there is a very specific scenario involving such an implement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Bruises: These are common in road traffic accidents due to blunt force trauma where the body strikes objects like the steering wheel, dashboard, or gets jostled against seat belts.

 

Option C. Graze Abrasion: Often occurs when the skin slides across a rough surface, such as in motorcycle accidents when the rider is dragged along the pavement.

 

Option D. Laceration: These are irregular tears in the skin commonly caused by blunt trauma, which is typical in road traffic accidents when sharp or rough metal edges and glass are involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chop wounds are unusual in road traffic accidents .

choices.text: Candida albicans
Candida tropicalis

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucormycosis

 

  • Voriconazole is an antifungal medication that is used for the treatment of a variety of fungal infections, including aspergillosis, candidiasis, and some types of cryptococcosis. However, it is not effective against mucormycosis, which is caused by fungi in the order Mucorales.
  • For the treatment of mucormycosis, alternative antifungal medications such as amphotericin B or posaconazole are usually used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Voriconazole is effective against Candida albicans, a common cause of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Candida tropicalis: Voriconazole is also effective against Candida tropicalis, another species of Candida that can cause infections.

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Voriconazole is highly effective against Aspergillus species, making it a first-line treatment for aspergillosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. For the treatment of mucormycosis, alternative antifungal medications such as amphotericin B or posaconazole are usually used.

questions.text: A 34-year-old individual residing in a slum has experienced diarrhea, constipation, and a weight loss of 2 kg over the past two months. Physical examination reveals a dry tongue and reduced skin turgor. An endoscopic biopsy of the gut displays the following microscopic features. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Giardiasis

 

Explanation:


The patient's symptoms and the results from the duodenal biopsy revealing pear-shaped structures suggest a diagnosis of Giardiasis. Giardia trophozoites, which have a characteristic pear shape and two nuclei of equal size, typically adhere closely to the brush border of villous enterocytes. Although these trophozoites do not invade the tissues, they can cause significant disruption to the host's digestive functions. The presence of such trophozoites in a resident of a slum, who has experienced significant gastrointestinal symptoms, is highly indicative of Giardiasis, especially given the environment which facilitates the spread of this parasitic infection.

 

Other options:


Option A. Entamoeba histolytica would show invasive amoebic ulcerations or flask-shaped ulcers in the colon rather than the pear-shaped trophozoites in the duodenum.
 

Option B. Whipple’s disease is characterized by the presence of foamy macrophages in the intestinal lamina propria, not the findings seen in the biopsy provided.
 

Option D. Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with gastric rather than duodenal biopsies and would show curved, rod-like bacteria on histology, typically with associated gastritis.

 

Educational Objectives:


The characteristic microscopic appearance of Giardia trophozoites in duodenal biopsies is indicative of Giardiasis. These trophozoites are pear-shaped with two equally sized nuclei and attach to the intestinal brush border without invading the tissue.

questions.text: A patient presents with perioral numbness, tingling, and tetany. All the following conditions can lead to this, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D toxicity

 

Vitamin D toxicity leads to hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia. Excessive vitamin D increases calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and mobilizes calcium from bones, leading to elevated serum calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Perioral numbness, tingling, and tetany are symptoms indicative of hypocalcemia. Various conditions can lead to hypocalcemia, each through different mechanisms:

 

Option B. Acute Pancreatitis: This condition can lead to hypocalcemia due to the sequestration of calcium in the inflamed pancreatic tissue and the formation of calcium soaps.

 

Option C. Chronic Kidney Disease: CKD results in hypocalcemia primarily due to decreased production of calcitriol (active vitamin D). The kidneys are unable to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to decreased calcium absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition, often resulting from surgical removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, leads to decreased production of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH is crucial for calcium homeostasis, and its deficiency results in hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D toxicity causes hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, distinguishing it from other conditions that can lead to hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

Other Options


Option A. Giardia lamblia: The stool examination usually reveals oval-shaped cysts or trophozoites. Giardia does not produce eggs, distinguishing it from helminthic infections.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs are typically oval-shaped and brown-colored. They have a distinct thick shell and are not barrel-shaped, which helps differentiate them from Trichuris trichiura eggs.

 

 

Option D. Ancylostoma duodenale:  The eggs are oval and thin-shelled, significantly different in appearance from the barrel-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: All of the following are true about grey rami communicants is all except: (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Preganglionic

 

Explanation:

 

  • The grey rami communicantes are not preganglionic fibers. They are postganglionic fibers.
  • In contrast, the white rami communicantes carry preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the spinal nerve to the sympathetic chain ganglia. Once in the ganglia, these fibers either synapse with postganglionic neurons, which return via the grey rami to spinal nerves, or ascend or descend to synapse at other levels.
  • The sympathetic trunks on either side of the vertebral columns consist of a series of ganglia. They are connected to the spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicantes. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic neurons are located in the lateral horn in the spinal grey matter. They leave the cord in the ventral nerve roots to form spinal nerves. These fibers enter the sympathetic trunk in white rami communicantes.
  • They synapse with the postganglionic sympathetic neurons in the sympathetic ganglia. The axons of the postganglionic neurons return to the spinal nerve through the grey rami communicantes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unmyelinated: True. Grey rami communicantes primarily contain unmyelinated postganglionic sympathetic fibers. These fibers are responsible for conveying the postganglionic sympathetic impulses to the spinal nerves, which then distribute these impulses to their target tissues.

 

Option B. Connected to spinal nerve: True. Grey rami communicantes connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to the adjacent spinal nerves. They are responsible for transmitting postganglionic sympathetic fibers to all spinal nerves (regardless of whether or not the spinal nerve level has a white ramus communicans).

 

Option D. Present medial to white rami communicantes: True. Anatomically, when observing the sympathetic chain and its connections to the spinal nerves, the grey rami communicantes are located medially (or more centrally) relative to the white rami communicantes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grey rami communicantes contain postganglionic, unmyelinated fibers that connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to spinal nerves, facilitating the distribution of sympathetic impulses to the body, contrasting with the preganglionic fibers found in white rami communicantes.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up after an abnormal Pap smear showing high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL). She has a history of HPV infection confirmed by previous testing. She is asymptomatic, with no family history of cervical cancer. Colposcopy and biopsy are planned to further evaluate the abnormal findings. During counseling, the physician explains the role of HPV in cervical carcinogenesis, emphasizing the involvement of specific viral proteins in disrupting cell cycle regulation. Which protein of the human papillomavirus (HPV) is responsible for the inactivation of the Rb gene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. E7

 

Explanation:

 

The E7 protein of human papillomavirus (HPV) plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of HPV-associated cancers by binding to and inactivating the Rb (Retinoblastoma) tumor suppressor gene. The Rb protein normally inhibits cell cycle progression by controlling the G1 to S phase transition, acting as a checkpoint to prevent uncontrolled cell proliferation. When E7 binds to Rb, it disrupts this regulation, leading to unchecked cellular growth, a hallmark of cancer development. This action is a central mechanism through which high-risk HPV types contribute to the development of cervical and other HPV-associated cancers.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E5
E5 is an oncogenic protein of HPV that enhances cell proliferation by interacting with growth factor receptors and altering cellular signaling pathways. Although it plays a role in HPV's oncogenic activity, it does not directly interact with or inactivate the Rb protein.

 

Option C. E1
E1 is involved in viral replication, functioning as a helicase that unwinds the viral DNA to allow replication within the host cell. It plays no role in the inactivation of tumor suppressor proteins like Rb and is not directly involved in oncogenesis.

 

Option D. L2
L2 is a minor capsid protein of HPV that plays a role in viral entry, assembly, and infectivity. It does not have any direct involvement in disrupting the cell cycle or inactivating tumor suppressor genes like Rb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E7 protein of human papillomavirus (HPV) binds to and inactivates the Rb tumor suppressor gene, disrupting cell cycle regulation and promoting uncontrolled cellular proliferation. This mechanism is crucial in HPV’s oncogenic process, leading to the development of cervical and other HPV-associated cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.

 

 

  • The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D. Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.
 

 

Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text:
In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. HbA1c >6.5
  2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL
  3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL
  4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care setting generally include the following criteria:

 

2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL: A fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL or higher on two separate occasions indicates diabetes. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.

 

3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL: A random blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL or higher, along with symptoms of diabetes, is sufficient for diagnosis. This test does not require fasting and can be taken at any time.

 

Other Options:

 

1. HbA1c >6.5%: While this test is beneficial for its ability to reflect average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months and does not require fasting, its higher cost and need for more sophisticated laboratory equipment make it less likely to be used at PHCs in India.

 

4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar: Part of the Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT), this test is more comprehensive but requires more time and resources, which may not be feasible in all primary care settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care (PHC) setting typically include fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL, and random blood sugar >200 mg/dL. These tests are widely accepted and feasible in most PHC settings.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

 

The structure marked A is ventral mesogastrium. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.

 

 

  • Mesogastriumis double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ (stomach) and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.
  • The ventral mesogastrium: is a structure found only in the foregut and is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum.
  • It is derived from the septum transversum and is divided into two parts by the growth of the liver into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum.
  • These two parts are the lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver, and the ligaments of the liver, which include all the liver ligaments except for the ligamentum teres.
  • The Dorsal mesogastrium: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut are connected to the posterior abdominal wall by the Dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The dorsal mesentery extends from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut and has specific names depending on the region it is found in.
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrosplenic Ligament: It is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It's a peritoneal fold that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessels run within this ligament.

 

Option B. Lienorenal Ligament: It is also derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney. As with the gastrosplenic ligament, it's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum.

 

Option D. Gastrophrenic Ligament: it is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It is the portion of the greater omentum (which also has its origins in the dorsal mesogastrium) that attaches the stomach to the diaphragm. It's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.

questions.text: A 60-year-old vegetarian patient presented with weakness and reduced work capacity. He had a Hb of 10gm/dl and MCV-110. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

 

  • Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by the presence of large, abnormal red blood cells (megaloblasts) in the bone marrow. It is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folic acid, both crucial for DNA synthesis in the production of red blood cells. The high mean corpuscular volume (MCV-110) indicates that the red blood cells are larger than normal, which is typical in megaloblastic anemia. Being vegetarian, the patient is at a higher risk of vitamin B12 deficiency, commonly seen in diets lacking in animal products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: Typically presents with a low MCV (microcytic anemia), not high, as it indicates smaller than normal red blood cells.

 

Option B. Aplastic anemia: Involves pancytopenia (reduction of all blood cell types) and does not typically present with high MCV.

 

Option D. Thalassemia: Generally presents with a low MCV and affects the production of hemoglobin. It is a genetic disorder rather than related to dietary habits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of anemia with high MCV, especially in vegetarians or those with dietary restrictions, megaloblastic anemia should be considered. Vitamin B12 and folate levels should be assessed to confirm the diagnosis, and dietary intake of these vitamins should be evaluated and corrected if deficient.

questions.text: The stain done on a section of liver shown below is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sweet’s reticulin stain

 

Stain demonstrates reticular fibers of the liver and hence has to be reticulin stain.

 

On microscope - plump hepatocytes are surrounded by rims of atrophic hepatocytes. The variation in parenchymal architecture is not easily seen on an H&E stain, and reticulin staining is required to appreciate the changes in hepatocellular architecture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warthin starry stain: This stain is typically used to identify organisms such as Helicobacter pylori or spirochetes and is not used for reticulin fibers.

 

Option B. Steiner silver stain: Steiner silver stain is used for the detection of certain microorganisms, like Legionella and Treponema, and is not related to reticulin fibers.

 

Option D. Grimelius silver stain: This stain is used for the detection of neuroendocrine cells by highlighting granules within these cells, and again, it is not related to the reticulin fibers of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sweet’s reticulin stain is specifically used to demonstrate reticular fibers in the liver, allowing for the visualization of changes in hepatocellular architecture that are not apparent with H&E staining.

questions.text: The extracellular concentration of chloride is 100mmol/L and the intracellular concentration is 10 mol/L. What is the equilibrium potential of chloride? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) - 60 mV

 

Nernst equation: EMF (millivolts) = [61/Z] X log [Co / C]

 

  • EMF = electromotive force (Nernst potential)
  • z = charge of ion
  • Co = concentration outside
  • C = concentration inside

 

When using this formula, it is usually assumed that the potential in the extracellular fluid outside the membrane remains at zero potential, and the Nernst potential is the potential inside the membrane.

 

The sign of the potential is negative (-) if a negative ion is diffusing from outside to inside.

Therefore, Nernst potential = 61/-1 * log [100/10] =-61 * log [10] = - 61 mV

 

To get the charge, always check the final charge intracellularly.

 

The potential is negative intracellularly, so the Nernst equation comes out to be -61mV inside the membrane and the closest option is -60 mV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The equilibrium potential for an ion can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

choices.text: Islets of Langerhans
Main Pancreatic Duct

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a known diagnosis of cystic fibrosis presents to the clinic with persistent abdominal pain, greasy stools, and poor weight gain despite a high-calorie diet. His past medical history is significant for recurrent respiratory infections and nasal polyps. On physical examination, he appears malnourished with a distended abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal low serum levels of pancreatic enzymes. An abdominal ultrasound shows evidence of pancreatic atrophy. A histological examination of the pancreas highlights prominent mucin accumulation and changes in the glandular structures. Based on the pathology findings, which pancreatic structure is primarily affected in patients with cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Acini (Exocrine Pancreas)

 

Explanation:

 

In cystic fibrosis, the exocrine pancreas, specifically the acinar cells (labeled 'B' in the provided histology image), is primarily affected. The disease is characterized by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to thick mucus production that obstructs the pancreatic ducts. This obstruction results in the accumulation of mucin and subsequent atrophy of the acinar cells, which are responsible for secreting digestive enzymes. Over time, this leads to pancreatic insufficiency, resulting in malabsorption, steatorrhea, and nutritional deficiencies commonly observed in patients with cystic fibrosis.



Other Options:

 

Option A. Islets of Langerhans
The islets of Langerhans, responsible for endocrine functions such as insulin secretion, are typically preserved in cystic fibrosis, especially in early disease. They are not the primary structures affected by the mucin accumulation and pancreatic ductal obstruction seen in this condition.

 

Option C. Main Pancreatic Duct
While the main pancreatic duct can be obstructed by thick mucus, leading to overall pancreatic dysfunction, the primary damage in cystic fibrosis occurs at the level of the acinar cells. The duct itself is not the main site of tissue atrophy but contributes indirectly to the damage.

 

Option D. Connective Tissue Septa
The connective tissue septa provide structural support to the pancreas but are not directly affected by the pathological processes in cystic fibrosis. The septa may become more prominent as acinar atrophy progresses, but they are not primarily involved in the disease’s pathogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cystic fibrosis, the exocrine pancreas, particularly the acinar cells, is primarily affected due to mucus accumulation and obstruction of the ducts, leading to acinar atrophy and pancreatic insufficiency. Understanding this pathology is crucial for recognizing the nutritional and digestive complications associated with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

 

Explanation:

 

Leaves of broad ligament:

 

  • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include:
    • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni: Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
    • Koblet’s tubules: Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
    • Epoophoron: Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
    • Para-oophoron: Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
    • Gartner’s duct: Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.

 

Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The liver biopsy histopathology of a patient diagnosed with hemochromatosis is shown below. Which stain has been used to obtain this image? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Prussian blue

 

Explanation:


The biopsy image provided demonstrates the presence of blue-black staining, characteristic of Prussian blue stain, which specifically targets iron deposits. In the context of hemochromatosis, a condition marked by excessive iron accumulation in the liver and other organs, the Prussian blue stain is utilized to detect the hemosiderin, an iron-storage complex. The iron in hemosiderin reacts with potassium ferrocyanide in the Prussian blue staining process, highlighting the affected areas in a blue-black color, confirming iron overload.

 

Other options:
 

Option A. Alcian blue is primarily used for staining acidic mucopolysaccharides and glycosaminoglycans in tissues, not iron.
 

Option C. Crystal violet is used for staining cell nuclei and not for iron.
 

Option D. Von Kossa stain is used to detect calcium deposits, not iron.

 

Educational Objectives:


Prussian blue stain is used to detect iron deposits in tissues, turning them blue-black, and is particularly significant in diagnosing conditions like hemochromatosis where iron overload is a key feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intranuclear immuno-histochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INSM

 

Intranuclear immunohistochemistry markers are specifically located within the nucleus of the cell, unlike cytoplasmic or membranous markers.

 

INSM (Insulinoma Associated Protein 1) is a novel intranuclear marker used for the detection of neuroendocrine tumors. It is particularly useful in diagnosing various types of neuroendocrine tumors, including small cell carcinoma of the lung, medullary thyroid cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma, and paraganglioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromogranin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option B. NCAM: Incorrect because it is a membranous marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option C. Synaptophysin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

INSM is an intranuclear marker for neuroendocrine tumors, distinguishing it from other cytoplasmic or membranous markers such as Chromogranin, NCAM, and Synaptophysin.

choices.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
Rigidity is pronounced
It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

 

Explanation

 

Decorticate animal is the one without cerebral cortex.

 

In man, decorticate condition is caused by intracranial hemorrhage, head injury, brain abscess or brain tumor. Decorticate condition is called decorticate rigidity

 

Decorticate rigidity is the abnormal postural changes that involve rigid extension of the lower limbs and flexion of the upper limbs at elbow joint across the chest. Wrists and fingers are also flexed. Posture may develop on one side or both sides of the body.

 

Reflexes at the neck level can be elicited

 

  • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs.
  • It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia: Incorrect as decorticate rigidity typically does not involve the removal of the basal ganglia.

 

Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs: Incorrect as this describes a reverse of the decorticate rigidity posturing.

 

Option C. Rigidity is pronounced: This statement is somewhat vague but could be considered true in the context of how muscle rigidity is indeed pronounced in decorticate rigidity. However, it does not specifically describe the characteristic posture associated with decorticate rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs, often occurring in response to severe brain damage above the midbrain level. It is a distinctive postural manifestation of significant central nervous system disruption.

choices.text: Chief cells
Stem cells
Parietal cells

questions.text: Cells lining the isthmus of the gastric pits? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem cells  

 

The isthmus of the gastric pits, which is the region between the gastric pit and the gland, contains stem cells. These stem cells are crucial for the continuous regeneration of the epithelial lining of the stomach. They have the potential to differentiate into all the different types of cells found in the gastric glands, including surface mucous cells, mucous neck cells, parietal cells, chief cells, and enteroendocrine cells. The high turnover rate of gastric epithelium necessitates the presence of these stem cells in the isthmus to replace the cells lost due to the harsh acidic environment of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chief cells: Chief cells are located in the base of the gastric glands and are responsible for secreting pepsinogen, which is the precursor to the digestive enzyme pepsin.

 

Option C. Parietal cells: Parietal cells are found in the neck and body of the gastric glands and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor, which is crucial for vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Option D. Mucous cells: Mucous cells, specifically surface mucous cells, are found lining the gastric pits and are responsible for secreting mucus that protects the stomach lining from the acidic environment. Mucous neck cells are located in the neck of the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus of the gastric pits is lined with stem cells, which are essential for the regeneration of the various cell types in the gastric glands, ensuring the maintenance of the gastric epithelium.

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

 

  • The provided clinical scenario presents a patient with symptoms of anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an accompanying image displaying hydrops fetalis.
  • These manifestations collectively suggest a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, commonly known as Fifth disease, which is caused by parvovirus B19.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

 

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

 

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

 

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Treponema pallidum (Syphilis) in pregnancy leads to subsequent pregnancy loss.

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) by trans placental spread causes fetal damage at all gestational ages. Features are periventricular calcifications, microcephaly, hearing loss, hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii intracerebral calcifications, hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Parvovirus B19 is responsible for severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and other serious complications in fetuses.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of hematuria. Upon examination, he is found to be normotensive and has pedal edema. Further investigations reveal a lack of glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. A renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below. Which of the following investigations should be conducted to identify the underlying disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti GBM antibodies

 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPG) is suspected based on the clinical history and microscopy showing crescents. Among the options presented, anti-GBM antibody testing should be performed because it is part of the RPGN work-up. 

 

HISTOLOGY:

 

Glomeruli — Regardless of the underlying cause, all forms of RPGN exhibit pathognomonic 'crescents' on the inside of Bowman's capsules. Crescents compress the glomerular tuft and obliterate the Bowman's space.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANA: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is used for diagnosing autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is more typically associated with Type II RPGN. It is not the primary investigation for Type I RPGN.

 

Option C. HIV RNA: This test is used for detecting HIV infection. While HIV can cause kidney disease, it is not specifically associated with the pathology seen in this case.

 

Option D. Urine immunoelectrophoresis: This test is used to detect abnormal proteins in the urine, such as in multiple myeloma. It is not relevant for diagnosing RPGN, specifically Type I RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testing for anti-GBM antibodies is crucial in the diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) with crescents on histology, particularly for identifying Type I RPGN (anti-GBM disease).

choices.text: Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban
Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban
Idarucizumab: Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match regarding FDA approved antidotes of anticoagulants? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ciraparantag: Fondaparinux

 

FDA-approved antidotes for specific anticoagulants are designed to counteract the effects of these drugs in cases of excessive bleeding or when rapid reversal is required for surgery or other urgent medical situations.

 

Ciraparantag is a broad-spectrum antidote that has shown effectiveness against various anticoagulants, including dabigatran, oral factor Xa inhibitors, low molecular weight heparins (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH), and fondaparinux. However, it is important to note that Ciraparantag is not currently FDA-approved for these indications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban: Andexanet alfa is an FDA-approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors, including Edoxaban, Apixaban, and Rivaroxaban. It works by binding to and sequestering the factor Xa inhibitors, thus reversing their anticoagulant effects.

 

Option B. Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban: Similarly, Andexanet alfa is also the antidote for Rivaroxaban, a factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Option C. Idarucizumab: Dabigatran: Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to Dabigatran, an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, and neutralizes its anticoagulant effect. This antidote is FDA-approved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Andexanet alfa is the approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors like Edoxaban and Rivaroxaban, while Idarucizumab is the antidote for Dabigatran. Although Ciraparantag has shown promise as a broad-spectrum antidote, it is not FDA-approved for use with fondaparinux or other anticoagulants.

questions.text: Which nerve is biopsied for the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic leprosy? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial branch of radial nerve

 

Superficial branch of radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy.

 

Pure neuritic leprosy is characterized by asymmetrical involvement of peripheral nerve trunks without visible skin lesions.

 

  • To confirm the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy, nerve biopsy is considered the gold standard. It is essential to biopsy only sensory nerves and avoid motor or major nerve trunks, as well as mixed nerves.
  • For nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy, the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is typically utilized.

 

 

  • The biopsy sample should be taken from a purely sensory thickened peripheral nerve, such as the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist, ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand, or sural nerve near the ankle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve and Option C. Ulnar nerve are less frequently chosen for biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy due to their mixed sensory and motor functions, which could lead to functional deficits if damaged.

 

Option D. Lateral popliteal nerve also known as the common peroneal nerve, is generally avoided in routine nerve biopsies for leprosy due to its deeper location and the significant motor components it controls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic Leprosy, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the preferred site for biopsy due to its accessibility, lower risk of complications, and high diagnostic yield.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.11 28.14

Sensory reanimation of the hand by transfer of the superficial branch of the radial nerve to the median and ulnar nerve - Scientific Figure on ResearchGate. Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Transfer-of-the-superficial-branch-of-the-radial-nerve-SBRN-to-the-median-nerve-MN_fig5_309138539 [accessed 9 Nov, 2023]

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestos

 

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura.

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the subpleural areas and in the bases of lungs. The advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

 

Gross appearance of the lung in asbestosis diagram

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • There is non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • There is presence of characteristic asbestos bodies in the involved areas. These are asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell-shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silica: Silica exposure leads to silicosis, which is characterized by nodular fibrosis, not asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Coal dust: Coal dust exposure leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) or "black lung disease," characterized by coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

 

Option D. Cotton: Cotton dust exposure leads to byssinosis, which is primarily associated with respiratory symptoms but does not cause the fibrosis and asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies and interstitial fibrosis, typically seen in individuals working in industries involving asbestos exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his developmental delays and behavior. A family history reveals that other male relatives have had similar developmental and behavioral issues. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome. Which of the following is NOT a feature of Fragile X syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Micro-orchidism

 

Explanation:

 

Fragile X syndrome is characterized by macro-orchidism (enlarged testicles), not micro-orchidism, especially noticeable in post-pubertal males. The syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CGG) in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome, leading to a deficiency in FMRP, a protein critical for neural development. Common physical features include a long face, large ears, prominent forehead, and behavioral problems such as intellectual disability and autism spectrum traits. The hallmark finding of macro-orchidism helps differentiate Fragile X syndrome from other genetic disorders.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Macro-orchidism
Macro-orchidism, or enlarged testicles, is a classic feature of Fragile X syndrome and often becomes more apparent during puberty. It is one of the key distinguishing characteristics seen in males with this condition.

 

Option B. Large ears
Large, often everted ears are a common feature of Fragile X syndrome and contribute to the distinct facial appearance. This feature, along with other craniofacial abnormalities, helps clinicians suspect the diagnosis in affected individuals.

 

Option D. Intellectual disability
Intellectual disability is a core feature of Fragile X syndrome, typically ranging from mild to severe. It is often accompanied by learning difficulties, speech delays, and behavioral issues such as anxiety and hyperactivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene, leading to macro-orchidism, intellectual disability, distinct craniofacial features, and behavioral challenges. It is important to recognize that macro-orchidism, not micro-orchidism, is characteristic of this disorder, helping to differentiate it from other genetic conditions.

choices.text: Fluctuant swelling in the hip
Cold abscess can develop from Pott's abscess
Pain on passive extension of hip joint is seen in patients and elderly
All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Psoas abscess are true? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Psoas abscess is characterized by a collection of pus in the iliopsoas muscle compartment, often resulting from an infection that may either be primary (from hematogenous spread) or secondary (from local extension). Here's why all the provided statements are true:

 

  • Fluctuant swelling in the hip: Psoas abscess may present as a fluctuant swelling that is palpable in the hip or groin area due to the proximity of the psoas muscle to these regions.
  • Cold abscess can develop from Pott's abscess: A Pott’s abscess, which is a form of spinal tuberculosis, can lead to the formation of a cold abscess due to spread of infection down to the psoas muscle along the sheath. This is considered a secondary psoas abscess.
  • Pain on passive extension of hip joint is seen in patients and elderly: This pain is due to the irritation of the psoas muscle, which is involved in hip flexion. Extension of the hip stretches the inflamed psoas muscle, causing pain.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fluctuant swelling in the hip: Directly related to the local presentation of a psoas abscess.

 

Option B. Cold abscess can develop from Pott's abscess: Demonstrates the connection between specific infections like tuberculosis and the development of certain types of abscesses.

 

Option C. Pain on passive extension of hip joint: This symptom reflects the physical discomfort caused by the stretching of the inflamed psoas muscle, common in psoas abscess due to its anatomical positioning and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the clinical presentation and etiology of psoas abscess, particularly recognizing that it can manifest with local hip symptoms, have a connection to spinal tuberculosis (Pott's abscess), and cause specific movement-related pain due to its anatomical location and function

questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. What is the most commonly affected area in Guillain-Barre syndrome? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1  

 

The myelin sheath is most commonly affected in Guillain barre syndrome which is marked as 1 in the above image.

 

Guillain-Barre syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP).

 

Infections with Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae, or prior vaccination, have been shown to have a significant epidemiologic association with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation (↑ protein with normal WBC count).
  • Nerve conduction studies: slowed conduction, conduction block.

 

Electron microscopy identifies an early effect on myelin sheaths. The cytoplasmic processes of macrophages penetrate the basement membrane of Schwann cells stripping away the myelin sheath from the axon. Ultimately, the remnants of the myelin sheath are engulfed by the macrophages. Remyelination follows the demyelination.

 

Label 2 – Axon:

 

  • This is the axoplasm or the central axon itself.
  • In axonal variants of GBS (such as Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy, AMAN, and Acute Motor and Sensory Axonal Neuropathy, AMSAN), the axon is directly attacked, usually by antibodies against axonal membrane components (e.g., GM1, GD1a gangliosides).
  • However, these variants are less common than the demyelinating type (AIDP).
  • So while axonal involvement can occur (especially in severe or axonal variants), it is not the most common target.

 

Label 3 – Schwann cell nucleus:

 

  • Schwann cells make and maintain the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system.
  • In GBS, the immune system generally attacks the myelin sheath rather than directly killing Schwann cells or their nuclei.
  • Damage to Schwann cells may occur secondarily, but it is not the primary target.

 

Label 4 – Schwann cell cytoplasm:

 

  • Similarly, the Schwann cell cytoplasm (outside the myelin) is not the main target.
  • The immune attack focuses on the compact myelin (label 1).
  • Schwann cells help with remyelination later but are usually not directly destroyed.

choices.text: Wilson's disease
Autoimmune hepatitis
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemochromatosis

 

The patient most likely has hemochromatosis. The liver microscopy image in the given scenario shows hepatocellular iron deposition is dark-brown in H&E stain (A) and blue in Prussian blue-stained section (B).

 

 

Hemochromatosis is defined by an abnormally high accumulation of body iron, the majority of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas. Iron can also build up in the heart, joints, and endocrine systems.

 

Hemochromatosis, also known as primary or hereditary hemochromatosis, is an inherited disorder caused by excessive iron absorption.

 

Secondary hemochromatosis, acquired hemochromatosis, or hemosiderosis refers to the accumulation of iron in tissues as a result of parenteral iron administration, usually in the form of transfusions, or other causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Primarily involves copper accumulation in the liver and other tissues, leading to liver disease and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

 

Option B. Autoimmune hepatitis: Characterized by inflammation of the liver due to autoimmune disorders, not associated with iron deposition.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency: Leads to liver and lung disease due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the liver, not iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron deposition in the liver and other organs, which can be confirmed by the distinct staining patterns seen in liver biopsy samples.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. It is the most common sporadic renal tumor
  2. Associated with loss of long arm of chromosome 3
  3. Arises from distal convoluted tubule
  4. Cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4  

 

CLEAR CELL CARCINOMA (Most Common variant)

 

  • Mutation - VHL gene (Occasionally associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome). Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3.
  • Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions.
  • Radiographic findings - Hypervascular mass with homogeneous enhancement
  • Gross: Solid mass with a golden-yellow appearance
  • Histopathology - Clear cytoplasm due to washing of accumulated glycogen and lipid droplets. Prominent vasculature and sheets of polygonal cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3, not long.

 

Statement 3: Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, not distal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clear cell carcinoma of the kidney is the most common sporadic renal tumor and is characterized by cells with intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat, as well as an association with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1847-1849

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Faggot cell

 

The picture shows multiple Auer rods clustered in a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks.

 

Such cells are called faggot cells (faggot meaning bundle of sticks in French). Faggot cells are characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) associated with the t(15;17) translocation.

 

The presence of faggot cells is particularly indicative of APL, where the leukemic promyelocytes have an abundance of Auer rods. Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules formed by the fusion of primary (azurophilic) granules. While Auer rods can be seen in other subtypes of AML, the clustering of these rods within a single cell to form a faggot cell is most commonly associated with APL.

 

Since the question is particularly about the cell, the best answer from the given options is faggot cell and not Auer rods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auer rods: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).

 

Option B. Flaming promyelocyte: Flaming promyelocyte is an abnormal promyelocyte with disintegrating cytoplasm and liberating Auer rods and granules into the surrounding marrow. Found in APL

 

Option C. Dusky promyelocyte: Promyelocytes with fine granules appearing dusky or hazy are called dusky promyelocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A faggot cell, characterized by multiple Auer rods clustered together in a single cell, is highly indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). While Auer rods are a feature of various forms of AML, the presence of faggot cells is particularly associated with APL.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1154

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with a pulsatile mass in the inguinal region. Imaging studies reveal a pseudoaneurysm involving an artery. What is the most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral artery

 

The femoral artery is a common site for pseudoaneurysm formation, especially in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: While pseudoaneurysms can occur in the aorta, they are less common than in peripheral arteries like the femoral artery.

 

Option C. Popliteal artery: Pseudoaneurysms can occur in the popliteal artery, but they are less common than in the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A pseudoaneurysm is a pulsatile hematoma that forms when there is a breach in the arterial wall, resulting in the extravasation of blood into the surrounding tissues.
  • The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation is the femoral artery, due to its superficial location and frequent use for arterial access.
  • Pseudoaneurysms can also occur in other arteries, such as the brachial, radial, ulnar, and carotid arteries.
  • Common causes of pseudoaneurysm formation include trauma, iatrogenic injury during medical procedures (e.g., arterial catheterization), and underlying arterial disease (e.g., atherosclerosis).
  • The clinical presentation of a pseudoaneurysm may include a pulsatile mass, pain, tenderness, and signs of bleeding or hematoma formation.
  • The diagnosis of a pseudoaneurysm is confirmed by imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT scan, or angiography.
  • Treatment options for a pseudoaneurysm may include observation, compression, percutaneous thrombin injection, or surgical repair depending on the size, location, and underlying cause of the lesion.
