  • MC site of true peripheral aneurysm is however, the popliteal artery.

questions.text: Match the following cells with their locations: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d  

 

The correct matches for the cells and their respective locations are as follows:

 

  1. Kupffer cells (b) Liver: Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver, involved in the breakdown of red blood cells and the immune response within the liver.
  2. Parietal cells (a) Stomach: Parietal cells are found in the lining of the stomach and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl), which aids in digestion.
  3. Dust cells (c) Alveoli: Dust cells, also known as alveolar macrophages, are found in the alveoli of the lungs. They play a crucial role in removing inhaled particles and pathogens from the alveolar spaces.
  4. Clara cells (d) Bronchioles: Clara cells, now more commonly referred to as club cells, are found in the bronchioles of the lungs. They secrete surfactant proteins and detoxify harmful substances inhaled into the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Natural deficiency of riboflavin in man is uncommon, because riboflavin is synthesized by the intestinal flora. Riboflavin deficiency usually accompanies other deficiency diseases such as beriberi, pellagra and Kwashiorkor. Nutritional status of riboflavin can be determined by measuring the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

 

Manifestations: Symptoms are confined to skin and mucous membranes.

 

  1. Glossitis (Greek, glossa = tongue)
  2. Magenta colored tongue
  3. Cheilosis (Greek, cheilos = lip)
  4. Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth)
  5. Circumcorneal vascularization
  6. Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries is the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency.
  7. Personality changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Deficiency causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, but is detected by erythrocyte transketolase activation assay.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy and is detected by activation of erythrocyte transaminases.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, detected by serum methyl malonate and homocysteine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency, indicated by reduced glutathione reductase activity, can cause symptoms such as a fissured tongue, cheilosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with 400 ml urine output in 24 hours. On histology he had crescents with pauci immune glomerulonephritis. What is the main etiology? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ANCA

 

The presence of crescents in a pauci-immune glomerulonephritis pattern is characteristic of ANCA-associated vasculitis. This type of vasculitis does not typically involve immune deposits (hence "pauci-immune") and is commonly associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). These antibodies are directed against constituents of neutrophil granules and monocyte lysosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti GBM antibody: This antibody targets the glomerular basement membrane, leading to Goodpasture's syndrome, which is typically not pauci-immune.

 

Option C. Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody: This is primarily associated with primary membranous nephropathy, which shows a different histological pattern.

 

Option D. Anti-nuclear antibody: While antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, which can involve the kidneys, lupus nephritis usually shows immune complex deposition, unlike pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ANCA-associated vasculitis is linked to pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, where crescents are formed in glomeruli without significant immune deposits, differentiating it from conditions such as Goodpasture's syndrome or lupus nephritis.

choices.text: Aschoff's bodies
Epithelioid granuloma
Granulomatous vasculitis

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

 

Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation. Aschoff's bodies are the most likely lesion in the histopathological slide.

 

Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues. Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epithelioid granuloma: Epithelioid granulomas are associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. They do not have the characteristic Anitschkow cells seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option  C. Granulomatous vasculitis: Granulomatous vasculitis is characterized by granulomas in the walls of blood vessels, which is seen in conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis. It does not match the histological description of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale: Granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with genital ulcers and Donovan bodies on histology, which is unrelated to the cardiac findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

choices.text: 5HT4 agonist
5HT2b agonist
5HT2b antagonist
5HT1a partial agonist

questions.text: Prucalopride is a (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 5HT4 agonist

 

PRUCALOPRIDE

 

  • It is a selective 5-HT4 receptor agonist approved recently for the treatment of chronic constipation, when other laxatives fail to provide adequate relief.
  • It activates pre-junctional 5-HT4 receptors on intrinsic enteric neurons to enhance release of the excitatory transmitter ACh. It, thereby promotes the propulsive contractions in ileum and more prominently in colon.
  • Prucalopride is shown to have negligible affinity for cardiac K+ channels. It is therefore, believed to be free of cardiovascular risk. No Q-T prolongation has been noted during clinical trial. 


Educational objective:

 

Prucalopride is a selective 5-HT4 receptor agonist used for the treatment of chronic constipation, working by enhancing acetylcholine release to promote intestinal motility without significant cardiovascular risks.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/724

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text: Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apoptosis

 

Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are both seen in apoptosis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Necrosis: Necrosis is a form of traumatic cell death that results from acute cellular injury. It is characterized by uncontrolled cell lysis, inflammation, and the release of intracellular contents into the extracellular space. Necrosis does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways seen in apoptosis.

 

Option C. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrosis that is caspase-independent but involves the receptor-interacting protein kinases (RIPK1 and RIPK3). It is similar to necrosis but is regulated and has distinct signaling pathways that do not include the intrinsic or extrinsic apoptotic pathways.

 

Option D. Pyroptosis: Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death associated with inflammation, typically involving caspase-1, which processes pro-inflammatory cytokines. It does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptosis is characterized by both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, which lead to programmed cell death in a controlled and regulated manner.

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day. What’s the source of glucose in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

 

  • Hepatic glycogenolysis involves the breakdown of glycogen stored in the liver into glucose. This process provides source of blood glucose for 12-18 hours, So By 7 am the next day, liver's glycogen stores is the main source of blood glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dietary Glucose: Dietary glucose from the previous evening's meal would have been absorbed and utilized or stored shortly after eating. By 7 am the next day, the influence of dietary glucose on blood glucose levels would have diminished significantly. It is unlikely to be the primary source of the elevated glucose.

 

Option B. Hepatic Gluconeogenesis: Hepatic gluconeogenesis is the process by which the liver produces glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors, such as amino acids and glycerol. During overnight fasting, the liver actively engages in gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels. It happens mainly only after 18 hours or more of fasting.

 

Option D. Muscle Glycogenolysis: Muscle glycogenolysis primarily supplies glucose for use within muscle tissue itself and is not a major contributor to blood glucose levels during fasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded).  After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer).

 

Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer).

 

Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 176

choices.text: EBV Negative
CD 30 Negative
CD 20 positive
Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

 

Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) is a subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma that is distinct from classical Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL). NLPHL is characterized by the presence of lymphocyte and histiocyte (L&H) cells, also known as "popcorn cells," which are CD20 positive and CD30 negative. Unlike classical Hodgkin lymphoma, NLPHL is typically EBV negative and has an excellent prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. EBV Negative: NLPHL is usually negative for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), distinguishing it from some subtypes of classical Hodgkin lymphoma, where EBV can be present.

 

Option B. CD30 Negative: CD30 is a marker typically expressed in classical Hodgkin lymphoma but not in NLPHL, making this statement true for NLPHL.

 

Option C. CD20 Positive: NLPHL cells express CD20, a B-cell marker, which is another feature that distinguishes it from classical Hodgkin lymphoma, where CD20 is typically negative.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmia’s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal distension and intermittent fever. Peripheral smear findings are normal. A tumor is resected and the histopathology image of the resected lymph node is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Castleman disease

 

The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing follicular hyperplasia of lymph nodes are suggestive of Castleman disease.

 

Castleman disease (angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia. is a lymphoproliferative disorder that can be associated with HHV-8 (multicentric Castleman disease or MCD. or idiopathic (unicentric Castleman disease or UCD).

 

4 subtypes –

 

  1. Unicentric CD (UCD. involves a single enlarged lymph node or multiple enlarged lymph nodes within a single lymph node region that demonstrate CD-like features under the microscope.
  2. Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)–associated multicentric Castleman disease (HHV-8–associated MCD. involves multiple regions of enlarged lymph nodes.
  3. POEMS-associated, HHV-8–negative MCD: POEMS (polyradiculoneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal plasma cell proliferative disorder, and skin changes) syndrome that co-occurs with HHV-8–negative MCD
  4. HHV-8–negative/idiopathic multicentric Castleman disease (iMCD. involves multiple regions of enlarged lymph nodes with CD-like features, flulike illness, abnormal blood counts, and dysfunction of vital organs (see Presentation) due to an unknown cause

 

There are 3 major histological subtypes:

 

  • Hypervascular (UCD) -
  • Lollipop appearance - atrophic germinal centers with radially penetrating blood vessels
  • Onion skin appearance of mantle zone around germinal centers

  • Plasma cell subtype (UCD or MCD - hypertrophic germinal centers, increased vascularity
  • Mixed variant (MCD. - mix of hypervascular and plasma cell subtype features in the same lymph node

 

The clinical features include:

 

  • Multiple enlarged lymph nodes
  • Night sweats
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

As this condition is associated with elevated levels of IL-6, the treatment involves IL-6 inhibitors like siltuximab and tocilizumab.

 

  1. Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) is a type of herpesvirus that is associated with several diseases, including:
  2. Kaposi's sarcoma (KS): HHV8 is the primary cause of KS, a type of cancer that causes the growth of abnormal blood vessels in the skin, mucous membranes, and other organs.
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL): HHV8 is also associated with PEL, a rare type of cancer that affects immune cells.
  4. Multicentric Castleman disease (MCD): HHV8 is implicated in the development of MCD, a rare disorder of the lymph nodes and related tissues that can cause fever, fatigue, and other symptoms.
  5. HIV-associated lymphomas: HHV8 is a co-factor in the development of some types of lymphomas, particularly those that are associated with HIV infection. E.g.: Plasmablastic lymphoma.

 

It is important to note that not all individuals infected with HHV8 will develop these diseases, and other factors, such as genetic susceptibility and immune status, may also play a role in disease development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Castleman disease is a lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by follicular hyperplasia and is associated with HHV-8 in some cases. The treatment involves IL-6 inhibitors due to the elevated IL-6 levels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a history of chronic abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. She has undergone multiple evaluations without a definitive diagnosis. A recent endoscopic biopsy of the colon was performed to further investigate her symptoms. The pathology report noted an abundance of mucin within the tissue, and the pathologist performed several special stains to differentiate the types of mucins present. The pathologist notes the presence of acid mucins in the biopsy sample and mentions the specific stain used to identify them. Which stain is used to identify acid mucin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Alcian blue

 

Explanation:

 

Alcian blue is a histochemical stain used specifically to identify acid mucins, which include acid-simple non-sulfated mucins, acid-complex sulfated mucins, and acid-complex connective tissue mucins. Alcian blue stains these acidic mucins blue, allowing for their clear visualization under the microscope. However, it does not stain neutral mucins, making it highly specific for detecting acidic mucin types in tissues. This staining is particularly useful in diagnosing mucinous lesions in the gastrointestinal tract and other organs where acid mucins are prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucicarmine
Mucicarmine is a specific stain for epithelial mucins, especially those found in adenocarcinomas. It is not used to identify acid mucins specifically, but rather highlights epithelial mucins, making it more useful in the identification of glandular tissues and certain tumors.

 

Option C. Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)
PAS stains both glycogen and mucins, including neutral and some acid mucins. It is a broad-spectrum stain that does not specifically distinguish acid mucins alone and can also highlight other carbohydrate-rich substances within tissues.

 

Option D. Colloidal iron
Colloidal iron stains acid mucins, including acid-simple non-sulfated and acid-complex sulfated mucins, but it does not stain connective tissue mucins. It is an alternative stain for acid mucins, but its specificity and utility differ from that of Alcian blue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcian blue is a histochemical stain that specifically identifies acid mucins, including both non-sulfated and sulfated types. It is widely used in pathology to highlight acidic mucin types in tissues, aiding in the diagnosis of mucin-producing lesions, particularly in the gastrointestinal tract.

choices.text: Cell cycle will stop at G2
Cell cycle will stop at G1
There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed
The cell cycle progresses and cell divides

questions.text: If the RB gene is hypophosphorylated, which of the following will happen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell cycle will stop at G1

 

If the retinoblastoma (RB) gene is hypophosphorylated, then cell cycle will stop at G1.

 

The Rb protein is a tumor suppressor, which plays a pivotal role in the negative control of the cell cycle and in tumor progression. It has been shown that Rb protein (pRb) is responsible for a major G1 checkpoint, blocking S-phase entry and cell growth by binding to and inactivating a transcription factor (E2F). The phosphorylation of RB results in the release of E2F activating gene transcription and cell-cycle progression occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cell cycle will stop at G2: This is incorrect because the Rb protein specifically regulates the G1 to S phase transition, not the G2 phase.

 

Option C. There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed: This is incorrect. The phosphorylation state of the Rb protein is crucial for its function in regulating the cell cycle. Hypophosphorylated Rb actively suppresses cell cycle progression at G1.

 

Option D. The cell cycle progresses and cell divides: This is incorrect because the hypophosphorylated form of Rb prevents the cell from progressing past the G1 phase, thereby halting cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypophosphorylated state of the Rb protein prevents the cell cycle from progressing past the G1 phase by binding to and inactivating E2F, thereby acting as a crucial checkpoint in preventing uncontrolled cell proliferation.

questions.text: A middle aged cement factory worker has developed mesothelioma. This is likely to be associated with: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

 

Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura (or less commonly, the peritoneum). The development of mesothelioma is closely linked with exposure to asbestos, which is commonly encountered in certain occupational settings, including cement factories.

 

Asbestosis:

 

  • Pathology: Asbestosis refers to chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers. The fibers can cause inflammation and scarring of lung tissue, leading to a restrictive lung disease.
  • Complications: Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the pleura or peritoneum.
  • Occupational Exposure: Cement factory workers, construction workers, and shipbuilders are at higher risk of asbestos exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Caused by inhalation of silica dust, leading to nodular pulmonary fibrosis. Not directly associated with mesothelioma.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Associated with coal dust inhalation, leading to coal worker's pneumoconiosis, not mesothelioma.

 

Option D. Byssinosis: Associated with cotton dust inhalation, leading to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, not mesothelioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, commonly found in occupations such as cement factory work, construction, and shipbuilding. Asbestosis can lead to significant complications, including mesothelioma.

 

Asbestos is a fibrous silicate mineral used in insulation, construction, and cement manufacturing.

 

  • Inhaled asbestos fibers lodge in the lungs and pleura, causing:
  • Interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Pleural plaques
  • Mesothelioma
  • Increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma
  • Even minimal exposure can be dangerous over time.

questions.text: Cancer that least commonly spreads by lymphatic route is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive tumor that rarely spreads by the lymphatic route.

 

Mutations in sonic hedgehog pathway are associated with it.

 

Grossly, the most common pattern is a nodulo-ulcerative basal cell carcinoma in which a slow-growing small nodule undergoes central ulceration with pearly, rolled margins.

 

 

The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC. may lead to confusion with melanoma.

 

It occurs exclusively on hairy skin, the most common location (90%) being the face, usually above a line from the lobe of the ear to the corner of the mouth. The most common site is the inner canthus of the eye.

 

 

Basal cell carcinoma does not show lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis. It is primarily locally invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatic system, particularly when occurring in the skin or mucous membranes.

 

Option B. Merkel Cell Carcinoma: This is a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer that frequently metastasizes via the lymphatic system.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: Melanoma is known for its high metastatic potential, often spreading through both lymphatic and hematogenous routes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is primarily a locally invasive tumor that rarely spreads via the lymphatic or hematogenous routes, distinguishing it from other more aggressive skin cancers.

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis
It is produced in response to bacterial infection.
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET)? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen

 

Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET). In classic NETosis, the DNA is nuclear, not mitochondrial.

 

Some rare reports suggest that under certain non-lytic forms, mitochondrial DNA may be extruded, but this is not typical of NETs as understood in bacterial infections or sepsis.

 

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are a network of neutrophil nuclear chromatin/DNA. The death of neutrophils is caused by the loss of nuclei. They assemble antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to combat bacteria and fungi (not viruses). During sepsis, they are detected in the blood.

 

They are produced by neutrophils in response to:

 

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is detected in blood during sepsis:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are indeed detected in the blood during sepsis as part of the body's response to widespread infection.

 

Option B. It is produced in response to bacterial infection:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are produced in response to bacterial infection as well as fungal infections.

 

Option D. It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes:

 

  • True Statement: NETs consist of chromatin (DNA) along with antibacterial enzymes and peptides, which help in trapping and killing pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are networks of nuclear DNA from neutrophils combined with antimicrobial enzymes and peptides, produced in response to bacterial and fungal infections. They play a crucial role in trapping and neutralizing pathogens. The presence of mitochondrial DNA in NETs is incorrect, as NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin.

questions.text: A woman, 35 years old, arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Her ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibody tests yield positive results. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The given patient presenting symptoms that indicate diffuse systemic sclerosis and dermatomyositis/polymyositis, is highly probable to have an overlap syndrome [Combinations of three connective tissue diseases, i.e., systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS) and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM)].

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are characteristically found in patients with overlap syndromes, which involve features of systemic sclerosis combined with polymyositis or dermatomyositis. These overlap syndromes involve a combination of autoimmune conditions, often including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS), and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Anti-U3 RNP antibodies are typically associated with systemic sclerosis but can be found in both limited and diffuse forms of the disease. They are not specifically linked to the overlap syndrome seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Anti-centromere antibodies are most commonly associated with limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), not the diffuse form or the overlap syndrome involving myositis.

 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are strongly associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, particularly with lung involvement, but they are less common than Anti-PM-Scl antibodies in patients with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are commonly associated with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis, making them the likely antibody in patients presenting with features of both conditions.

questions.text: What is the content of given vacutainer? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper, hence it contains clot activator

 

Red stopper plastic tubes contain silica as a clot activator.

 

The tubes are inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Use – Serum Analysis, Serology tests, Blood banks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: EDTA is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a lavender stopper for hematological tests such as complete blood counts (CBC).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: This anticoagulant is used in light blue stopper tubes, primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and APTT.

 

Option C. Na-heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a green stopper, commonly for plasma biochemistry tests.

 

Educational Objective:
